-Clinic

*polyuro-polydipsic syndrome: look for hyperglycaemia
*dehydration: think of hyperglycaemia
*acute abdominal pain in children and adults|abdominal pain]], [[Nausea SD-012|nausea]]: think of ketosis
*adrenergic signs in a diabetic (sweating, pallor, tachycardia): think of hypoglycaemia
*disturbance of vigilance: think of hyper or hypoglycaemia: calm coma: hyperglycaemia, agitated coma: hypoglycaemia [[Coma and consciousness disorders SD-028]].

- Organic

*hyperglycaemia greater than 2.5 g/l: ketone levels should be measured
*hypoglycaemia <70 mg/l, life-threatening <54 mg/l, severe if re-sugaring by a third party is required or associated loss of alertness
*dehydration or renal failure, remember to check blood glucose, if high: ketonemia and osmolarity

'''see previous chapter on hyperosmolar coma, ketoacidosis and hypoglycaemia'''

question.title: Identifying an acute metabolic complication in a diabetic patient
question.description: What should you consider when a child or adult presents with abdominal pain and nausea?

option_a.title: Both hyperglycaemia and ketosis
option_a.description: This option suggests considering both hyperglycaemia and ketosis as possible causes of abdominal pain and nausea in a diabetic patient

option_b.title: Only hyperglycaemia
option_b.description: This option suggests considering only hyperglycaemia as a possible cause of abdominal pain and nausea in a diabetic patient

option_c.title: Only ketosis
option_c.description: This option suggests considering only ketosis as a possible cause of abdominal pain and nausea in a diabetic patient

option_d.title: Neither hyperglycaemia nor ketosis
option_d.description: This option suggests considering neither hyperglycaemia nor ketosis as a possible cause of abdominal pain and nausea in a diabetic patient

correct_option.title: A
correct_option.description: The correct answer is 'Both hyperglycaemia and ketosis'
